timeline.message: Basic setup for rerunning enhancements from admin interface

* Pass object type from form
* Wire up enhancement stream
* Add runEnhancements permission
Use datastream classes instead of splitting metadata locally

* Add header needed to pass through enhancement filters
* Switch the way derivative directories are created
Add IT test for running enhancements

timeline.bodyText: you can remove this permission for all users except administrators
timeline.author: bbpennel

timeline.bodyText: Might as well make a constant out of this
timeline.author: bbpennel

timeline.bodyText:
For this block, I don't think it can receive anything other than an IOException, so you should probably change the catch to that. Also, it'd probably be good to add the exception as the cause of the exception you end up throwing.
You may also not need this log statement. If you feel like it is useful though, it might be good to add a little more info to it, like the PID of the object that failed was, or the path of the file. This might already be covered by the exception you through though, which will end up in the logs.
timeline.author: bbpennel

timeline.bodyText: Hmm, this route kind of doesn't do anything anymore. I'm tempted to remove it to skip a step, but i think that's going to happen anyways in one of the follow up tickets so i think this is okay for now

timeline.bodyText: I wrote this? Also, add a description of the class
timeline.author: bbpennel

timeline.bodyText:
If possible, use @PostMapping , and also there's a constant that you can use for the produces type org.springframework.http.MediaType.APPLICATION_JSON_VALUE.
Also, you're not using either request or response, i think you can remove both
timeline.author: bbpennel

replies.bodyText: Was wondering about that. Seems some of our controllers pass in request, response, but don't always use them.
replies.author: lfarrell

timeline.bodyText:
I'd recommend just passing the ids of the objects to process in rather than passing in the object type too. You can retrieve the object type from the ids using RepositoryObjectLoader, which should be more trustworthy as well.
Additionally, its usually a best practice to not specify a concrete implementation for collections unless you really need to, so you should change this to just List<String>
timeline.author: bbpennel

timeline.bodyText: This service is a singleton, so you can't hold onto variables that are only used for a single invocation, otherwise there will be problems if the service is invoked twice at the same time. recordInfo is only used in createMessage anyways, so it should be very easy to declare it as local to that. Although I'd recommend changing the name too, its a datastream rather than a record
timeline.author: bbpennel

timeline.bodyText: how about datastreams instead of ids since there's a lot more info in there than ids?
timeline.author: bbpennel

timeline.bodyText: Use the constant for this, which is available at edu.unc.lib.dl.model.DatastreamType.ORIGINAL_FILE.getId()
timeline.author: bbpennel

timeline.bodyText:
Use the interface here, List<String>. Also, related to my comment in the controller, just pass in the ids and then use a repositoryObjectLoader.getRepositoryObject to get the object type according to the server. Then you can do instanceof to see what kind of object it is.
Also, you can change Boolean force to the primitive boolean force since you don't appear to be expecting a null value, and you're using the primitive over in the controller
And you should also add javadoc for this method. It can be brief, but helpful to describe what the params are.
timeline.author: bbpennel

timeline.bodyText: you can put "runEnhancements" directly into the message since its not coming from a variable or constant.
timeline.author: bbpennel

timeline.bodyText:
Since all of our enhancements are for files at the moment, you could limit the search to just return file objects. You can do that by adding a facet filter, something like:
searchState.getFacets().put(SearchFieldKeys.RESOURCE_TYPE.name(), ResourceType.File.name());
timeline.author: bbpennel

timeline.bodyText: Hmm, I think you can remove this catch and leave it up to the thing that calls it to decide whether or not to log the error. Similarly, you might want to add some logging to the controller to log the error in the catch block it already has.
timeline.author: bbpennel

timeline.bodyText: doesn't matter too much, but maybe submit the value "true"?
timeline.author: bbpennel

timeline.bodyText: Totally optional, but wanted to mention that you could pass RunEnhancementsRequest into the service as the input rather than PIDS and force separately. I don't really have that much of an opinion on this though. If you do, you might want to move the declaration of this class into the service though.
timeline.author: bbpennel

timeline.bodyText:
use
throw new IOException("Failed to create parent directories for " + derivativePath, e);
timeline.author: bbpennel

timeline.bodyText: Might be helpful to state that it searches for file objects which are in the list of pids or children of those objects.
timeline.author: bbpennel

timeline.bodyText: If you call createFileObject(null) then it will make a PID for you and you don't have to worry about collisions between test runs. You can get the pid back by calling fileObj.getPid(). This would allow you to remove hard coded pids too.
timeline.author: bbpennel

timeline.message:
* Remove hard coded variables
* Update error message and javadoc

* Remove hard coded variables
* Update error message and javadoc
Use the PID from the solr result when submitting objects for enhancements from service.
Make MessageSender into its own class, inject into RunEnhancementService so that it can be mocked for testing, allowing much more detailed verification
